work.cod_n: unsure if inland or coastal raid

data.name: Long-distance Mos raids
data.desc: Mos raid a Sp settlement, possibly marking first instance of Mos hostilities
data.prim_n: GUATEMALA,299 ff 92-95, 146v-49 [Betancourt a Berrera a 17 ago 1699 / Concepción, Barrientos a Durado a 26 ago 1699]
data.note:
See 1699 Mos Shore map in Thornton 13
 2 Jun 1704 Alvarado reports Mos raid captured 8 men, 12 women, 20 boys / c 1710 Mos raid captures Chontal Indians /v Thornton 21 /GUATEMALA,299 ff 153v-54, 156 /GUATEMALA,300 f 84v
 c 1708-1709 Mos raids in Costa Rica /v Thornton 26 fn 60 / See León Fernández, *Colección de documentos para la historia de Costa Rica*, vol 9 [Barcelona, Viuda de Luis Tasso, 1907], 72-119
 c 1709 or 1710 [?], Pres of Guat Toribio de Cosio, and Obispo of Nicaragua Francisco Benito Garret, informed re. Mos-Jam alliance, inc raids on Lemoa [near Golfo Dulce], San Antonio [Sp Hon?], and river towns on Río San Juan [near Verapaz] cf Bib Real DIG/II/2822 ff 312r-347r /v Barke H 174 fn 603
 Though see, 1692 'The 'zambos mosquitoes' penetrated the Caribbean coasts on three occasions 'taking more than 200 people of their natives' in AFEHC Link: https://www.afehc-historia-centroamericana.org/index_action_crono/
 Possibly see, 21 Jun 1740 Chiriqui Lagoon [Mos Shore] Hodgson to Trelawny. Reports sev Mos elders informed him that during King William and Queen Ann's wars [1688-1713] the King's Ships and Privateers came to Mos Shore to sponsor Mos raids [on Sp and Amerindians, for captives] in a more regular fashion [than at present] / See confirmation by Bishop Garret y Arloví in M. M. Peralta, *Costa Rica y Costa de Mosquitos: Documentos para la Historia de la jurisdicción territorial de Costa Rica y Colombia* [Paris, sn, 1898], 43-63 /v Offen M 51 /LC Vernon-Wager Force Collection 1740 series 8D/11 reel 92
 1702 San Pedro Sula [Sp Hon] attacked by zambos [Mos] / 1704 Fuerte [Castillo] de San Felipe attacked by zambos /v Lujan 3 683
